articles.headline: WhatsApp’s New Feature Continues Facebook’s Snapchat Mimicry
articles.snippet: With Facebook and some of its top apps trying to tap into popular features pioneered by Snapchat, WhatsApp unveiled a version of its Status feature that focuses on sharing images.
articles.abstract: With Facebook and some of its top apps trying to tap into popular features pioneered by Snapchat, WhatsApp unveiled a version of its Status feature that focuses on sharing images.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook offered $3 billion to buy the ephemeral messaging app Snapchat in 2013. Snapchat’s founder, Evan Spiegel, turned down the offer.

articles.headline: From an Anchor’s Lips to Trump’s Ears to Sweden’s Disbelief
articles.snippet: A diplomatic dispute with Sweden illustrates the unusual approach the president takes to foreign policy, as well as the influence that television can have on his thinking.
articles.abstract: A diplomatic dispute with Sweden illustrates the unusual approach the president takes to foreign policy, as well as the influence that television can have on his thinking.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — On Friday night, Fox News aired an alarming six-minute segment in which the host, Tucker Carlson, interviewed a documentary filmmaker about a crisis of violence in Sweden ignited by the recent wave of Muslim migration.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Sewell Chan

articles.headline: Trump Chooses H.R. McMaster as National Security Adviser
articles.snippet: The president called him “a man of tremendous talent and tremendous experience.”
articles.abstract: The president called him “a man of tremendous talent and tremendous experience.”
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Trump appointed Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster as his new national security adviser on Monday, picking a widely respected military strategist known for challenging conventional thinking and helping to turn around the Iraq war in its darkest days.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Does Bigfoot Have a Soul? A Radio Host’s Audience Ponders
articles.snippet: The millions of nocturnal listeners who tune in to “Coast to Coast AM” are fans of unexplained phenomena.
articles.abstract: The millions of nocturnal listeners who tune in to “Coast to Coast AM” are fans of unexplained phenomena.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the C.I.A. released hundreds of thousands of declassified files online in January, the contents probably seemed far-fetched to most people. Included in the cache were documents about U.F.O. sightings, demonstrations of psychic abilities and reports of a Georgian man with magical healing powers.
articles.byline: By Jonah Engel Bromwich and Bonnie Wertheim

articles.headline: Europe Combats a New Foe of Political Stability: Fake News
articles.snippet: The rise of sophisticated hacks and a torrent of fake news coincide with angry populist movements across the Continent, and officials are nervous.
articles.abstract: The rise of sophisticated hacks and a torrent of fake news coincide with angry populist movements across the Continent, and officials are nervous.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — They scan websites and pore over social media, combing through hundreds of reports a day. But the bogus claims just keep coming.
articles.byline: By Mark Scott and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: With Snap’s I.P.O., Los Angeles Prepares to Embrace New Tech Millionaires
articles.snippet: That prospect has real estate agents, money managers and luxury goods purveyors excited for a potential business windfall, of the sort often seen in Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: That prospect has real estate agents, money managers and luxury goods purveyors excited for a potential business windfall, of the sort often seen in Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Blaine Lourd has long helped the movie stars, professional athletes and heiresses in Los Angeles manage their wealth. Over the past few years, he has also noticed millionaires who made their money in technology begin to dot the west side of the city.

articles.headline: How an Interoffice Spat Erupted Into a Climate-Change Furor
articles.snippet: A retired scientist became a hero to some climate-change deniers after he criticized his former boss at NOAA over data handling.
articles.abstract: A retired scientist became a hero to some climate-change deniers after he criticized his former boss at NOAA over data handling.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, on an obscure climate-change blog, a retired government scientist named John Bates blasted his former boss on an esoteric point having to do with archiving temperature data.

articles.headline: For-Profit Schools, an Obama Target, See New Day Under Trump
articles.snippet: The Education Department, whose scrutiny has led hundreds of campuses to close, is now led by Betsy DeVos, who has investments in the industry.
articles.abstract: The Education Department, whose scrutiny has led hundreds of campuses to close, is now led by Betsy DeVos, who has investments in the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Election Day, for-profit college companies have been on a hot streak. DeVry Education Group’s stock has leapt more than 40 percent. Strayer’s jumped 35 percent and Grand Canyon Education’s more than 28 percent.

articles.headline: Trying to Stanch Trinidad’s Flow of Young Recruits to ISIS
articles.snippet: Officials in Trinidad and Tobago are scrambling to close a pipeline that has sent a steady stream of Muslims to Syria to take up arms for the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: Officials in Trinidad and Tobago are scrambling to close a pipeline that has sent a steady stream of Muslims to Syria to take up arms for the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: ENTERPRISE, Trinidad and Tobago — By the time he was 17, Fahyim Sabur had memorized the Quran.

articles.headline: Unease Spreads in Atlanta as a City Contracting Scandal Brews
articles.snippet: A brick thrown through a window, dead rodents left on steps and a threat to a contractor have become symbols of a federal inquiry into bribery charges.
articles.abstract: A brick thrown through a window, dead rodents left on steps and a threat to a contractor have become symbols of a federal inquiry into bribery charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The brick, marked with a threatening message, crashed through the window of a prominent contractor’s dining room here in September 2015, apparently sometime between dusk and dawn. For some time, news of the incident failed to reverberate much beyond the home itself.

articles.headline: At Town Halls, Doses of Fury and a Bottle of Tums
articles.snippet: Some Republican legislators encountered boos and hostile questions. One attendee gave a senator some antacids because he was “going to need them.”
articles.abstract: Some Republican legislators encountered boos and hostile questions. One attendee gave a senator some antacids because he was “going to need them.”
articles.lead_paragraph: FAIRVIEW, Tenn. — Representative Marsha Blackburn may have expected to draw a friendly crowd by scheduling a town hall-style meeting in a Tennessee community that had voted overwhelmingly for President Trump, but she instead faced a hurricane-strength blast of disapproval on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel, Thomas Kaplan, Lizette Alvarez and Emmarie Huetteman
